title: Britain set to face a ‘BITTER CONFLICT’ if peers heed Blair & thwart Brexit, says Hague
text:
6 'It can be stopped, if the British people decide that having seen what it means, the pain-gain analysis doesn’t stack up' 
“It is not in the interests of our democracy and the governance of the country to do so.” 
Lord Hague launched his warnings as Theresa May intently watched the peers debate the law which will trigger the start of negations about Britain’s exit from the European Union next month. 
The Prime Minister is the first in living memory to watch a debate on legislation in the Lords, but Boris Johnson later took her seat in the House after she left. "We cannot be leaving the EU in 2017, and remaining in it in 2018, and leaving it again in 2019" Lord William Hague 
Lord Hague’s comments were met with opposition as former Labour Cabinet minister Lord Mandelson said the Government had “lost its sense of perspective” on Brexit with its priority being “assuaging the ideologues” rather than trade, investment and jobs. 
He added: “I was a Remainer. Not I might say because of my pension rights but because I am a patriot. A patriot rather than a nationalist.” GETTY Cherie Blair looks on as husband Tony claimed people voted in the referendum without knowledge 
Opposition peers shouted “shame” as Lord Lawson said amendments already tabled would “delay” the Bill. 
Insisting clarity should be met, Lord Hague added: “We cannot be leaving the EU in 2017, and remaining in it in 2018, and leaving it again in 2019 an day 2020 to be too confused about what we are doing.” Related articles
